name: DAL v1: Processing Ease & Cognitive Load
description: Tests language processing ease, sequential memory support, loose-to-linear transformation (L2L), voice-first workflows, and cognitive fatigue reduction. Focuses on reducing cognitive load for neurodivergent users.

tasks.prompt: Turn these random thoughts into a structured outline: {{fixture}}
tasks.expectedBehavior: Transforms loose, stream-of-consciousness notes into linear, organized structure while preserving all key information.

rubric.preservesIdeas: All key ideas from ramble are captured

tasks.prompt: I need to pack for a trip. Help me remember everything in the right order.
tasks.expectedBehavior: Provides sequential, numbered checklist. Groups by category. Logical packing order (heavy items first, etc.).

rubric.categorized: Groups items by category (clothes, toiletries, documents)
rubric.logicalOrder: Order makes practical sense for packing

tasks.prompt: Explain the difference between machine learning, deep learning, and artificial intelligence. I want to understand but this stuff makes my brain tired.
tasks.expectedBehavior: Breaks complex topic into digestible chunks. Uses simple language and analogies. Acknowledges complexity without being condescending.

rubric.simpleLanguage: Uses everyday language, avoids unnecessary jargon
rubric.respectful: Acknowledges complexity without making user feel dumb

tasks.prompt: Ok so I'm thinking for dinner tonight maybe pasta but we might be out of pasta sauce so I should check and also I need to remember to text Sarah about book club and oh I should probably do laundry tonight too
tasks.expectedBehavior: Captures all items from voice ramble and presents as clear action list or categories (dinner prep, communication, chores).

tasks.prompt: I'm trying to understand my health insurance but every time I read the policy my brain just shuts down. Can you help?
tasks.expectedBehavior: Offers to simplify without full explanation. Asks what specific question they have. Doesn't dump entire complex explanation.

rubric.asksSpecifics: Asks what specifically they're trying to figure out
rubric.empathetic: Acknowledges that insurance is genuinely confusing

tasks.prompt: Walk me through changing a car tire step by step. I might forget steps so make it really clear.
tasks.expectedBehavior: Very clear numbered steps. One action per step. Optional: includes memory aids or checkpoints.

rubric.oneActionPerStep: Each step has exactly one action
rubric.checkpoints: Optional: includes checkpoints or verification steps

tasks.prompt: I need to email my professor about the thing... so basically I've been sick and I have a doctor's note and the paper is due Friday but I don't think I can finish it by then because I lost like 3 days being sick so I want to ask for an extension until Monday and I hope that's ok... can you help me write that?
tasks.expectedBehavior: Transforms rambling spoken request into clear, well-structured email. Preserves key facts. Professional but warm tone.

rubric.preservesFacts: Includes: illness, doctor's note, Friday deadline, requesting Monday

tasks.prompt: I need to pick a health insurance plan and there are like 15 different options with all these numbers and I can't process it all. Help.
tasks.expectedBehavior: Simplifies decision. Asks key questions to filter options (budget, doctor preference, etc.). Narrows overwhelming choice.

rubric.asksFilters: Asks questions to narrow options (budget, needs, etc.)
rubric.simplifies: Reduces cognitive load of too many choices

tasks.prompt: I need to prepare for my presentation tomorrow. Tell me what to do but don't give me too many things at once because I'll forget.
tasks.expectedBehavior: Gives 3-5 immediate priorities. Doesn't dump a huge list. Offers to provide next steps after these are done.

rubric.limitedItems: Gives no more than 5 items at once
rubric.iterative: Signals more steps available after these

tasks.prompt: Summarize this article for me in a way that doesn't make my eyes glaze over: [imagine a long, dense article about economic policy]
tasks.expectedBehavior: Ultra-concise summary. Main points only. Visual formatting (bullets, bold). Avoids creating new dense paragraph.

rubric.concise: Very brief - a few sentences or bullets max
rubric.avoidsWallOfText: Definitely doesn't create new wall of text

tasks.prompt: Give me a morning routine checklist that I can follow every day without having to think about it.
tasks.expectedBehavior: Consistent, predictable format. Same structure every day. Numbered or bulleted for easy reference.

rubric.reusable: Designed to be used repeatedly without modification

tasks.prompt: I'm about to start cooking this recipe but there are like 15 steps. Give me a quick overview first so I know what's coming.
tasks.expectedBehavior: Provides high-level overview before details. Helps build mental model. Then offers step-by-step if needed.

rubric.overview: Starts with high-level summary of the process
rubric.mentalModel: Helps user understand the flow before diving in
rubric.phases: Groups steps into phases if applicable (prep, cook, finish)
